[[Paris]], [[France]] |instrument = [[Vocals]], [[piano]] |genre = [[Rhythm and blues]] |occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] |years_active = 1949–1984 |label = Apollo, [[Aristocrat Records|Aristocrat]], Parrot, [[Chess Records|Chess]], Federal, Mad, Formal, USA, [[Storyville Records|Storyville]], Blues On Blues, [[Black & Blue Records|Black and Blue]], America, Ornament, L+R |website = }} '''Willie Mabon''' (October 24, 1925 – April 19, 1985)[http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Willie-Mabon.html Oldies.com biography - accessed January 2008] was an [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] and [[pianist]]. ==Career== Born '''Willie James Mabon''',[http://www.wirz.de/music/mabonfrm.htm Discography fansite - accessed January 2008] and brought up in [[Hollywood, Memphis|Hollywood]], [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]], he had become known as a singer and pianist by the time he moved to [[Chicago]] in 1942. He formed a group, the Blues Rockers, and in 1949 began [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] for the [[Aristocrat Records|Aristocrat]] [[record label|label]], and then [[Chess Records|Chess]]. His biggest success came in 1952 when his debut solo release, "[[I Don't Know (Willie Mabon song)|I Don't Know]]", topped the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B chart]] for eight weeks.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | page= 139}} It was one of the most popular releases of its era, becoming Chess's biggest [[hit single|hit]] in the period before [[Chuck Berry]]'s and [[Bo Diddley]]'s success. It also became one of the first R&B [[hit record]]s to be [[cover version|covered]] by a leading [[white people|white]] [[musician|artist]], [[Tennessee Ernie Ford]]. Mabon's original was played on [[Alan Freed]]'s early [[radio]] shows and also sold well to white audiences, crossing over markets at the start of the [[rock and roll]] era. Mabon returned to the top R&B slot in 1953 with "I'm Mad", and had another hit in 1954 with the [[Mel London]] song "Poison Ivy". However, his career failed to maintain its momentum, and record releases in the late 1950s on a variety of [[record label]]s were largely unsuccessful. Releases in the 1960s included "I'm The Fixer" and "Got To Have Some". After a 1972 move to Paris, Mabon toured and recorded in [[Europe]] as part of promoter Jim Simpson's ''American Blues Legends'' tour, recording ''The Comeback'' for Simpson's [[Big Bear Records]] label, and his 1977 album on [[Ornament Records]].{{cite web |url= http://www.wirz.de/music/ornament.htm|title= Ornament Discography|first1= Stefan |last1= Wirz|date= January 8, 2010|work= American Music|publisher= |accessdate=January 30, 2010}} He also performed at the [[Montreux Jazz Festival]]. In April 1985, after a long illness, Mabon died in Paris.[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.comn - accessed November 2009] ==Legacy== *"[[I Don't Know (Willie Mabon song)|I Don't Know]]" was [[cover version|covered]] by [[The Blues Brothers]] in 1978. *His song "Just Got Some" was covered by [[Rod Stewart]]. *His song "I'm Mad" is featured in the [[Marv Newland]] 1980 animated short [[film]], ''Sing Beast Sing.'' *"[[The Seventh Son (song)|Seventh Son]]", first recorded by Mabon in 1955, has since been covered by a number of artists including [[Johnny Rivers]], [[Georgie Fame]], [[John Mellencamp]], [[Billy "Crash" Craddock]], [[Mose Allison]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Climax Blues Band]], and [[Long John Baldry]].
